extracted.completion:
The freezing point of a solution is lower than that of the pure solvent. The amount of depression in freezing point can be calculated by the formula:

$$\Delta T_f = \frac{nRT_{\text{melt}}^2}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}$$

Where:
- n is the amount of substance (in mol) of ions in the solution
- R is the gas constant
- T_{\text{melt}} is the melting point of pure water
- \Delta H_{\text{melt}} is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water

Given:
- Density of pure water: 1 g cm^{-3}
- Melting point of pure water: 273 K
- Standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water: 6.01 kJ mol^{-1}
- Concentration of sodium chloride solution: 3 mol dm^{-3}

To find the freezing point of the solution, we need to calculate the amount of sodium chloride in moles per liter of solution:

$$n = (3 \text{ mol dm}^{-3})(10^{-3} \text{ dm}^3/\text{L}) = 3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ mol/L}$$

Substituting the values into the formula above, we get:

$$\Delta T_f = \frac{(3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ mol/L})(8.314 \text{ J/mol K})(273 \text{ K})^2}{6.01 \times 10^3 \text{ J/mol}}$$

$$\Delta T_f = -0.81 \text{ K}$$

Therefore, the freezing point of a 3 mol dm^{-3} solution of sodium chloride is:

$$273 \text{ K} - 0.81 \text{ K} = \boxed{272.2 \text{ K}}$$

$$2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)$$

$$\Delta H_f^°[CH_4] = -74.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$$

$$\Delta H_f^°[H_2O] = -285.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$$

$$\Delta H_c^°[H_2] = ?$$

Using the standard enthalpy of formation, we can write:

$$\Delta H_c^°[H_2] = -2\Delta H_f^°[H_2] - \Delta H_f^°[H_2O] $$

$$ \Delta H_c^°[H_2] = -2(0 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}) + (285.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1})$$

$$ \Delta H_c^°[H_2] = \boxed{285.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}}$$

The ratio of moles of acid to moles of NaOH is 1 : 1, so the amount of acid in the sample is:
